publicationStmt.p: Scholarly digital edition of the manuscript by Paolo Monella.

sourceDesc.p: The digital images of the manuscript.

revisionDesc.change: file:///usr/share/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/AI.html#AILC: The c (character) element should be used to mark up any non-lexical character, whether this appears within a word, or outside it. In the following example, the encoder wishes to indicate that the letters are not to be regarded as words:
Alcuni attributi (ad es. force, function, e altri) hanno valori di datatype data.enumerated. Questo significa che dovrei limitare formalmente i possibili valori con un elemento valList?
Nella documentazione in [sgn4] metti parole vuote con 0 o no?
Si potrebbero trascrivere anche le glossae a margine
È rispettata o no la regola sulle due forme di 'ti': una con legatura per IPA /tsj/?
Find sources for ab006 based on the comments on Donatus (find ab006 and 'note' there)
Togli la punteggiatura 'solo contemporanea' (senza corrispondenza nel MS)?
Cose da fare alla fine dell'intera trascrizione:
vd. se ci sono 'v', o 'ae', o grafemi non dichiarati in GToS, in grafematica
vd. se i brevigrafi (þ, ŋ etc.) hanno per_lo_più o sempre il signif. che suggerisco nella GToS

ref.note: This title (marked as 'head') is in uncial. Another GToS for the uncial script would be necessary.
ref.w: grammatice In this case the diphthong 'ae' seems to be written with grapheme 'e', not 'æ', however the writing is too little legible to ascertain this.

add.note: Under the well readable 'pars' written above the line, there's another word, hardly readable probably because of a hole in the parchment. The deleted word might also be 'pars'.

ref.note: This is a triangle pointing downwards, but I'm not sure whether this is the same as the punctuation paragraphematic sign that I'm marking as ','
I don't understand this word made of three letters and the following "n with tilde" sign, which might be an abbreviation for 'non'.

unclear.w: legeIt seems that something similar to 'ut lege' was written in the same line, then was erased and a new 'ut lege' was written in its place. Also, there is a faded sign over the initial 'u'. This sign looks like a French circumflex accent and already occurred earlier in the same line (above the previous 'ut').
ut There is a faded sign over the initial 'u'. This sign looks like a '^' accent and already occurred earlier in the same line (above the previous 'ut').
est The ink is faded here, however it is possible to see a sign above the 'e'. It might mark the fact that the sentence is interrogative.

ab.n: De oratione: introduction to the parts of speech

ref.note: For section ab0006 Morelli 1910, 291 mentions the following sources: "Donato K. IV. 372 25 sgg. e commentatori di Donato; Prisc. 54 segg." Donatus and Priscianus are imitated quite loosely in this section. I should inquire better about the commentaries on Donatus though. More specific imitations on Priscianus included in this section are referenced directly. Possible comments on Donatus might include: (A) Seruius, K.4.405-K.4.448. For example K.5.81-K.5.312 and in particular on the parts of speech K.5.134 ff." For section ab0006 Morelli 1910, 291 mentions the following sources: "Donato K. IV. 372 25 sgg. e commentatori di Donato; Prisc. 54 segg." Donatus and Priscianus are imitated quite loosely in this section. I should inquire better about the commentaries on Donatus though. More specific imitations on Priscianus included in this section are referenced directly. Possible comments on Donatus might include: (A) Seruius, K.4.405-K.4.448. For example see K.4.428.8 ff. for the parts of speech and lines 11-13 in particular (on page 428 a new author starts: Seruius/Sergius); (B) Pompeius K.5.81-K.5.312 and in particular on the parts of speech K.5.134 ff.
There seems to be a peculiar punctuation sign here, that I am not encoding because I'm not sure about it.
From this column, the handwriting, the script and also the punctuation conventions seem to be different.

Here Ursus follows Priscianus 2.54.8 closely. The source has: "partes igitur orationis sunt secundum dialecticos duae, nomen et |uerbum, quia hae solae etiam per se coniunctae plenam faciunt orationem"

unclear.note: In fact, if we include the 'interiectio', the parts of the speech become six, not five as announced.

ref.note: The Greek name for 'aduerbium' is not written. In its place, another hand has put what seems to be a pointer to a marginal glossa. The latter glossa is unfortunately illegible.

ref.note: This punctuation mark looks like a horizontal dash. It seems to be an allograph for the paragraphematic sign 'middle dot'.
This punctuation mark looks like a horizontal dash.

From this point on, I'm marking the text with the help of an external Python script. First, I mark the text by using my own simplified 'markdown' conventions, then I run the script that converts that 'markdown' to XML/TEI markup.

ref.w: substantie In this case the diphthong 'ae' seems to be written with grapheme 'e', not 'æ'.
aer Note that here 'ae' is no diphthong, it is written with two separate graphemes 'a' and 'e'.

ref.note: Morelli 1910, p. 291, n. 3 corrects 'inpura' to 'in pure' and comments: "Cod. inpura. Correggo secondo la fonte di Ursus, Virg. gramm. p. 85,23 Huemer: 'Pus in philosophia custodia dicitur, ut ait Origenes: Positis in pure fratribus solus evasit'.
ref.w: estimabant In this case the diphthong 'ae' is written with grapheme 'e', not 'æ'.

ref.w: greco In this case the diphthong 'ae' is written with grapheme 'e', not 'æ'.

nomaOn the linguistic layer (LL), this word won't be able to be processed by a parser, as it does not exist in common dictionaries. Priscianus means this to be a previous (no longer existing) form of the word ὄνομα.

add.note: This is an explanatory interlinear glossa. In the mansucript, it is linked to the main text by means of a cross sign between 'nascitur' and 'ut'. The text in the glossa is closer to the text of Priscianus (the source of this passage).

ref.w: athomas I am not sure whether the lemmatizer will be able to parse this word.
grecos In this case the writing is too little legible to ascertain whether the diphthong 'ae' is written with 'e' or with 'æ'.
ignouiliThis might be an error of the scribe for 'ignobili'.

fuissetOne ore more words of this sentence are illegible, so the specific syntax of the sentence is unclear. However, I would have expected 'fuisse' here, while I think that a 't' is clearly readable at the end of the word.

þ per
sone In this case the diphthong 'ae' is written with grapheme 'e', not 'æ'.
coeperit In this word, the diphthong 'oe' is written with two graphemes 'o', 'e'.
bitio The scribe made a u/b spelling mistake here.
ref.note: After 'numerantur', there is a light 'c-like' sign that I am interpreting as an allograph of the middle dot grapheme.
Morelli 1910, p. 292 writes that the passage connecting the terms for the four types of proper names to future infinitives has no ancient source.
ref.w: infiniti The scribe made a grammar mistake by writing 'infiniti' for 'infinitis'.

w.note: This grapheme looks like a 'p' with both a bottom-left tail (which would make it a 'ŋ' sign, abbreviation for 'pro') and a horizontal dash crossing the descending trait (which would make it a 'þ' sign, abbreviation for 'per'). Probably the same hand first wrote the abbreviation for 'per', than changed his mind and added the bottom-left tail that made it an abbreviation for 'pro'.

ref.w: abitu Spelling mistake: omission of the initial 'h', unvoiced at the time of the scribe.

ab.n: De nomine: definition of appellatiua nomina

ref.note: The rest of the line is blank, and is filled with a note from another hand, in a different script and black (not brown) ink. In the rest of the column, the same black ink was used to restore faded graphemes.

ab.n: De nomine: types of appellatiua nomina

ref.w: sunt This piece of the page was either damaged or (more probably) erased, then the word was written by another hand in black ink. Graphemes 'nt' are written above the line.
ref.note: The word 'sunt' and the first three graphemes of 'incorporales' ('inc') are written in black ink, possibly over a correction.
ref.w: synonima The initial 's' is written with black ink.

gentile The initial 'g' is written in black ink. It is apparent here that the first hand (writing in brown ink) had written this 'g' with its regular shape and size, and the second hand (writing in black ink) derased the original 'g' and wrote it over the rasura with a larger grapheme in capital form. All word initial graphemes in lines 31-35 are in black ink. Some of them are clearly written over a rasura.

patri
u2 um
The larger initial grapheme is written in black ink over a rasura (same situation as 'gentile' above).
relatiua The larger initial grapheme is written in black ink over a rasura (same situation as 'gentile' above).
patronomica The source Priscianus Keil 2.60.2 has 'patronymicum'.
ref.note: In this case the diphthong 'ae' seems to be written with grapheme 'e', not 'æ'.
ref.w: gradidus Both 'd's in the manuscript seem to be due to a correction (by overwriting). The second 'd' was originally a 'b': on the one hand, the '-ibus' ending is very common in Latin; on the other hand, 'b' for 'u' was a common spelling error due to the contemprorary pronunciation of Latin. I cannot read what was originally written over the current first 'd'.

enno
sigeus In this case the diphthong 'ae' seems to be written with grapheme 'e', not 'æ'.

ŋ pro
prio
r
u2 um

qu
æ2 em
admod
u2 um
Strangely enough, 'em' here is abbreviated with 'æ' and the '2' abbreviation sign. Also, while we tend to write 'quemadmodum' as one word, and as such I am encoding it at the Lingustic Layer, the scribe spells it as two words, with a graphical space in between: 'quem' 'admodum'. In consideration of the fact that the scribe often writes 'ad' with no space after it, it might also be that the scribe is writing this expression as three separate words: 'quem', 'ad' and 'modum'.

qų qu
od The source (Priscian, Ars grammatica, 2.60.19) has: 'Ad aliquid dictum est, quod sine intellectu illius, ad quod dictum est, proferri non potest'. Also, in the only previous instance of the 'ų' abbreviation mark (a 'u'-like sign over the 'q'), in 1v.a.3, the word is 'quod'. However, in 1v.a.3 the last two graphemes were clearly 'o' and 'd', while here the sign(s) after the 'q' and 'u'-like abbreviation mark are less clear to me.

qu
a2 am
qu
a2 am
ref.note: Over the words 'quis', 'qualis', 'quantus' and 'quot' the scribe wrote a horizontal dash meaning their interrogative role in a sentence. Over 'quotus' this sign has the shape of a French circumflex accent.
ref.w:
substan
tieIn this case the diphthong 'ae' seems to be written with grapheme 'e', not 'æ', however the writing is too little legible to ascertain this.
mouilisThe scribe wrote 'mouili': an error facilitated by the contemporary pronunciation.

ge
neriThe scribe mistakenly wrote 'generi' instead of 'generis'.
nonumFor 'tertiusdecimus' and 'nonumdecimum', I think that the scribe meant to write the two components of each word ('tertius' and 'decimus', as well as 'nonum' and 'decimum') separately.
uicesimusThere is a macron over the 'e' of 'uicesimus', but I don't understand what function it could have here.
decimusThere is a macron over the 'e' of 'uicesimus' and over the 'c' of 'decimus' in this line, but I don't understand what function they could have here.

qu
a2 am
qu
a2 am

nongentesi
m; mus
This is a fairly rare case in which the final ';' abbreviation mark is used to mean a final '-us' morpheme. Also, the last 'n' in 'nongeNtesimus' is written above the line.

epimerizomenaThe source of this passage is Priscian 'De figuris numerorum' (Keil 3.413.24) and has ἐπιμεριζόμενα. The handwriting in the manuscript is almost completely faded, especially the letters after 'epi-' and before '-omena'. However, based on the number of graphemes that seem to be in this word the scribe probably wrote a shorter word than ἐπιμεριζόμενα, possibly something like 'epirizomena'.

¢ qui
nquiesThe 'n' is written above the line.
